block.p: The American Museum of Natural History, dogged by a reputation for stodginess despite recent renovations, is planning a major reconstruction and expansion intended to bring it into the realm of the latest generation of interactive science museums. The centerpiece of the plan is a huge sphere that would replace the 59-year-old Hayden Planetarium. A1. NEW YORK CITY

The American Museum of Natural History, dogged by a reputation for stodginess despite recent renovations, is planning a major reconstruction and expansion intended to bring it into the realm of the latest generation of interactive science museums. The centerpiece of the plan is a huge sphere that would replace the 59-year-old Hayden Planetarium. A1. NEW YORK CITY

The president of York College made political contributions with college funds, billed the school twice for some moving and travel expenses and spent $272,000 in public funds for the renovation of her official residence, college and City University officials said. B3. JURY IS CHOSEN FOR CONSPIRACY TRIAL

A jury including a letter carrier, two people who work with computers, a transit worker and an accountant was selected in the terror conspiracy trial of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and 11 others. B3. ADVOCATE OF CIVIL RIGHTS DISBARRED

C. Vernon Mason, an outspoken lawyer, was disbarred by a state appellate court, which cited him for "a pattern of professional misconduct" spanning at least six years. B3. SCHOOL BOARD TO INVESTIGATE REMARKS

A Community School Board in southeast Queens agreed last night to investigate the remarks of an assistant principal at an elementary school after parents said he disparaged black children and their ability to swim. B3.
The bullets that killed a theft suspect did not come from the gun carried by a man arrested minutes after the shooting, the police said. B3. REGION POLICE AGENCY INQUIRY ASSAILED

An untrained police department bungled the 1991 investigation into the murder of a Westchester infant in the care of a Swiss nanny, failing to take such steps as examining the charred plastic seat where the baby died and a cloth soaked in lighter fluid found near the nanny's bed, a state commission has concluded. B5. CORNELL PROFESSOR FACES SANCTIONS

Based on sexual harassment complaints from four former students, a Cornell University ethics committee has recommended sanctions against James B. Maas, a prominent psychology professor known both for his research on sleep and for the dozens of educational films and television specials he has produced. B5. PATAKI ANNOUNCES PATRONAGE CUTS

Gov. George E. Pataki announced that he would eliminate 22 percent of the political appointments controlled by the Governor to save $29 million a year. As a percentage, that cut would satisfy Mr. Pataki's campaign pledge to reduce at least 20 percent of the state's patronage jobs. But the number of jobs fell far below the number he used during the campaign. B4. WHITMAN TAKES BUDGET ON ROAD
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey moderated a statewide televised town meeting about her 1996 budget proposal. B4.
The Los Angeles police have begun an investigation into the death of Doris Duke. B4.
Governor Whitman named a rest area in honor of the radio host Howard Stern. B4. Neediest Cases B2 Our Towns by Evelyn Nieves B5
